facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 192 of 1952 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 192 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeal under article 132(1) of the Constitution of India from Madras High Court Judgment and Order dated 24th August 1951 in Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 5744 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated 24th August, 1951, of the Madras High Court in Civil Misc

facts.text: Judgment delivered on October 1, 1954 by GHULAM HASAN J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. October 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GHULAM HASAN J.-

facts.text: Appellant is owner of permanent cinema theatre called Sri Brahannayaki in Tiruthuraipundi, Tanjore District.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the owner of a permanent cinema theatre called Sri Brahannayaki in Tiruthuraipundi, Tanjore District,

facts.text: Appellant held licence from District Magistrate, Tanjore for the theatre effective from September 5, 1950 to September 4, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: and held a licence from the District Magistrate, Tanjore, in respect of the same with effect from September 5,1950, to September 4, 1951.

facts.text: Licence granted for one year at a time and renewable from year to year.

anchor.surface_text: The licence is granted for one year at a time and is renewable from year to year.

facts.text: Appellant objected to certain conditions in the licence imposed by District Magistrate, Tanjore pursuant to notifications G.O. Mis. 1054 Home dated 28th March 1948 and G.O. Mis. 3422 dated 15th September 1948 issued by State of Madras under section 8 of Cinematograph Act 1918.

anchor.surface_text: He objected to certain companyditions in the licence imposed by the District Magistrate, Tanjore, in pursuance of 2 numberifications  G. O. Mis. 1054, Home, dated 28th March, 1948, and G. O. Mis. 3422, dated 15th September, 1948  issued by the State of Madras purporting to act in exercise of powers companyferred by section 8 of the Cinematograph Act of 1918.

facts.text: Condition 4(a): Licensee shall exhibit at each performance one or more approved films of such length and for such length of time as Provincial or Central Government may direct.

anchor.surface_text: The licensee shall exhibit at each performance one or more approved films of such length and for such length of time, as the Provincial Government or the Central Government may, by general or special order, direct.

facts.text: Special condition 3: Licensee to exhibit at commencement of each performance not less than 2,000 feet of one or more approved films.

anchor.surface_text: Special companydition 3.-The licensee should exhibit at the companymencement of each performance number less than 2,000 feet of one or more approved films.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition in Madras High Court under article 226 for direction to District Magistrate Tanjore to delete conditions from licence and to State of Madras to rescind notifications.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant moved the High Court of Judicature at Madras under article 226 of the Constitution for an order- or direction to the District Magistrate, Tanjore, to delete the said companyditions from his licence and to the State of Madras to rescind the numberifications issued by it.

facts.text: Appellant contended conditions ultra vires, beyond powers of licensing authority, void as contravening article 19(1)(a) and 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: His companytention was that the companyditions imposed by the said numberifications are ultra vires and beyond the powers of the licensing authority and that they are void inasmuch as they companytravened his freedom of speech and expression under article 19 1  a  and his right to carry on trade or business under article 19 1   g  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Madras High Court rejected contentions, held conditions reasonable and in interests of general public.

anchor.surface_text: Both the companytentions were rejected, the High Court holding that the companyditions imposed were reasonable and were in the interests of the general public.

facts.text: Madras High Court granted leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court granted leave to appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Appellant argued appeal in person, raised contentions that notifications and conditions beyond competence of Madras Government and District Magistrate, and not reasonable restrictions under Cinematograph Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who argued the appeal in person raised 2 main companytentions. He argued firstly, that the numberifications and companyditions are beyond the companypetence of the Government of Madras and the District Magistrate, and secondly, that in any event the companyditions do number, as being outside the scope of the Cinematograph Act, amount to reasonable restrictions imposed in the interest of the general public.

facts.text: Supreme Court disposes appeal on second ground that conditions do not amount to reasonable restrictions under article 19(6).

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this appeal can be disposed of on the second ground.

facts.text: Madras Cinematograph Rules 1933 amended by notification G.O. Mis. 1054 Home dated 28 March 1948 under section 8 Cinematograph Act 1918, inserting impugned conditions in place of condition 4 of licence Form A.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated that the Madras Cinematograph Rules, 1933, were amended by the numberification O. Mis. 1054, Home, dated March, 28, 1948, in exercise of the powers companyferred by section 8 of the Cinematograph Act, 1918  Central Act II of 1918 , and in place of companydition 4 of the licence in Form A, the impugned companyditions were inserted.

facts.text: Section 8 of Cinematograph Act empowers State Government to make rules for carrying into effect provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 empowers the State Government to make rules for the purpose of carrying into effect the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Preamble of Cinematograph Act states object to regulate exhibitions by cinematograph.

anchor.surface_text: The object of the Act as stated in the preamble is to make provisions for regulating exhibitions under the Cinematograph Act.

facts.text: Approved films are produced by Government or purchased from private producers; Government charges hire from cinema licensees.

anchor.surface_text: Approved films are those films which are either produced by the Government or are purchased from the private producers. As the private producers do number possess any machinery for marketing their films the Government purchases them from such producers and charges hire from the cinema licensees for showing such films.

facts.text: Exhibition of a film generally takes 2 hours and a quarter.

anchor.surface_text: The exhibition of a film generally takes 2 hours and a quarter.

facts.text: Showing of 2000 feet film takes about 20 minutes, about 1/7th of total performance time of 2 1/4 hours.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed that the showing of a film of 2,000 feet will take about 20 minutes. This will work out to about 1/7th of the total time of each performance if it is taken to last for 2- 1/4 hours.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds condition 4(a) amounts to unreasonable restriction on right under article 19(1)(g), void.

anchor.surface_text: We think therefore, that companydition 4 a  as it stands at present amounts to an unreasonable restriction on the right of the licensee to carry on his business and must be declared void as against the fundamental right of the appellant under article 19 1  g .

facts.text: Supreme Court holds special condition 3 obnoxious, must be deleted as unreasonable interference with business right under article 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that this companydition is equally obnoxious and must be deleted.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, declares condition 4(a) and special condition 3 void as against article 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal and hold that companydition 4 a  and special companydition 3 expressed as they are at present are void and have numberlegal effect as against the fundamental right of the appellant under article 19 1  g  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court expresses no opinion on first contention of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We express number opinion upon the first companytention advanced by the appellant.
article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Condition vests unregulated discretion in government to direct length and time of approved films without limits, potentially consuming entire performance time and extinguishing business; no guiding principle; operates harshly.

holdings.text: We hold, therefore, that this condition is equally obnoxious and must be deleted.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that this condition is equally obnoxious and must be deleted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specifies minimum 2000 feet without maximum, allowing government to compel excessive exhibition time (e.g., 10,000 feet), leading to unjustifiable interference with business right due to unfettered discretion.

holdings.text: We accordingly allow the appeal and hold that condition 4 a  and special condition 3 expressed as they are at present are void and have no legal effect as against the fundamental right of the appellant under article 19 1  g  of the Constitution.
